page.title: 02FARMING IN SOUTH LINCS
page.content: The land to the west side of Bourne is mainly farmland - a mixture of arable and grassland.Corn, oil seed rape and sugar beet are the main crops. Sheep, beef cattle and horses are reared on the grasslands. After combining farmers have the facilities for drying their corn ready for marketing. The farms are highly mechanised, large modern machinery having replaced most of the labour force. Adjacent woodlands provide cover for deer, foxes and game which encroach on farmland causing damage to crops. An old custom used on one farm to discourage deer is that of obtaining human hair from a local hairdresser to put into old onion nets, which are then attached to boundary posts.
